message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory test results suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray is a classic finding in primary hyperparathyroidism. Options B, C, and D are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum calcium level and elevated parathyroid hormone suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-rays is a characteristic radiologic finding in this condition. Option B describes multiple myeloma, Option C describes metastatic disease, and Option D describes tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated calcium, low phosphorus, and elevated alkaline phosphatase, along with the symptoms and history, suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray is a common finding in this condition. Osteopenia, osteolytic lesions, and pathological fractures are more indicative of advanced bone disease or bone metastases. Lytic changes in early stage and a sclerotic picture in later stage are seen in multiple myeloma. Fibronodular opacities in upper lobes of the lung with or without cavitation suggest tuberculosis or fungal infections, which are not related to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s high serum calcium level, high parathyroid hormone, and elevated urinary calcium level suggest hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray is a classic finding of hyperparathyroidism. Osteopenia, osteolytic lesions, and pathological fractures are seen in multiple myeloma. Lytic changes in early stage and sclerotic picture in later stage is seen in metastatic bone disease. Fibronodular opacities in upper lobes of the lung with or without cavitation are seen in tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum calcium level, high parathyroid hormone, and elevated urine calcium level suggest hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption is a radiologic finding consistent with hyperparathyroidism. The other options are not consistent with hyperparathyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum calcium, low phosphorus, and elevated parathyroid hormone levels suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common radiologic finding in this condition is subperiosteal bone resorption, which can be seen on hand X-rays. Option B is more consistent with multiple myeloma, option C with metastatic bone disease, and option D with tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum calcium and high parathyroid hormone levels suggest hyperparathyroidism. The radiologic finding consistent with this condition is subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray. Option (B) is more indicative of multiple myeloma, option (C) is more indicative of metastatic bone disease, and option (D) is more indicative of tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s high calcium level, high parathyroid hormone, and elevated 24-hour urine calcium suggest hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption, especially in the hands and feet, is a common finding in hyperparathyroidism. Osteopenia, osteolytic lesions and pathological fractures are common in multiple myeloma, Lytic changes in early stage and a sclerotic picture in later stage suggest metastatic carcinoma, and fibronodular opacities in upper lobes of the lung with or without cavitation suggest tuberculosis or sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's high serum calcium, high parathyroid hormone, low phosphorus, and elevated 24-hour urine calcium level suggest hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray is a classic finding in hyperparathyroidism. Options B, C, and D are not consistent with the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated serum calcium levels and high parathyroid hormone with low phosphorus and mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. Subperiosteal bone resorption on hand X-ray is a classic finding in primary hyperparathyroidism. Option B, osteopenia, osteolytic lesions and pathological fractures, are more common in multiple myeloma. Option C, lytic changes in early stage and sclerotic picture in later stage, is more common in metastatic bone disease. Option D, fibronodular opacities in upper lobes of the lung with or without cavitation, is more common in tuberculosis or fungal infections of the lung.
